text: Welcome to AnimationHub. In this
tutorial, we're going to take a look at
vectors for stylized comic materials.
Let's get to it. In the content browser,
right click and create a material.
Double click the material to open the
material editor.
Set the metallic setting to one. Set the
specular setting to zero and set the
roughness setting to one as well.
Click in the graph area and press the
tab key and type sky atmosphere light
direction and hit the enter key to
generate the node. Click the graph area
and press tab key and type pixel normal
world space and hit the enter key to
generate that node.
Drag from the outpin of the sky
atmosphere light direction node and type
do to generate the dot operator node.
Connect the outpin of the pixel normal
world space to the B pin of the product
node. Now dragging from the outpin of
the dot operator node, type power and
hit the enter key to generate that power
node. Drag from the outpin of the power
node and type multiply and hit the enter
key to generate the multiply node. Drag
from the multiply node and type subtract
and hit the enter key to add the
subtract node.
For the power multiply and subtract
nodes, rightclick and promote to
parameter for each of the open settings.
Connect the out pin of the subtract node
to your base color and emissive settings
on the material.
To see the results, save the material
and close the graph.
In the content browser, rightclick the
material and select create material
instance.
Drag the material instance onto the mesh
in the level.
Double click the material instance to
adjust the parameters of the material to
your liking. Now the material can be
extended to have the best of both
vectors.
In the graph area, press the tab key and
generate a camera vector whirlpace node.
Drag off of the sky atmosphere light
vector outpurp
and hit the enter key to generate a
linear interpolation node. Connect the
camera vector world space to the B slot
of the linear interpolation node. Right
click on the alpha pin and promote to
parameter. Name this vector blend. And
this will allow for blending to and from
each of the different vectors. Either
the vector coming from the light or the
vector coming from the camera.
That's it. See you next time.
